Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Multiple contemporaneous comments called him a ‘god’; one commenter heralded the task as ‘the pinnacle of human brain potential.’
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: contemporaneous comments; one commenter heralded the task

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: A sample comment on one of his practice runs, months before he made history: ‘that performance... no other way to describe it but... FUCKING LEGENDARY.’
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: sample comment on one of his practice runs

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: ‘I had no idea he could do shit like that,’ someone uttered in the crowd, in awe, in a video of his display.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: in a video of his display

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: for his prowess at pretending to play the song, the Guinness Book awarded him a record for best Guitar Hero player in the world.
Document Sources.Source Justification: for his prowess at pretending to play the song

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: telling the New York Times he wanted to buy a multi-thousand dollar DDR arcade cabinet.
Document Sources.Source Justification: he wanted to buy a multi-thousand dollar DDR arcade cabinet

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: ‘It wasn't anything serious,’ he told Gazetteer SF over FaceTime from his home in Hayward. ‘I wasn't extremely good at the game or anything.’
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: told Gazetteer SF over FaceTime from his home in Hayward

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: ‘He's the GOAT,’ according to friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast. ‘Everybody knows it. No one would deny it.’
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend; San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: ‘We’re learning to pay for things when we have the money,’ his mom, who reportedly managed those deals, told the outlet.

‘I don’t think I would have any other reason to take it so seriously if it wasn’t for the community and the competition,’ he said. ‘You discover this group of people who’s really like-minded. It’s a really rare thing, because out in the normal world, there’s not a lot of people who think like me or have similar hobbies or have the grinder mentality for video games like me.’
‘Whenever you meet someone who plays DDR, you kind of don't really care that much what they're doing outside of the game, right?’ Clark said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: ‘I was, like, I get to quit and have severance at the same time — it was almost a win-win, ‘cause I was already a little bit checked out,’ he said.
‘I don't think I can physically do this forever,’ he said. ‘I'm getting up there, I just turned 33 this week. So I'm just taking advantage of it while I can.’
‘This is the best that anyone in the human race could possibly achieve at this thing,’ Clark told Gazetteer.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: in 2009, he started at the University of Pennsylvania.
